oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Anita Bryant Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Tape 2 of 2. Recording of an interview with Anita Bryant (performer) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Anita Bryant; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Anita Bryant talks about her parents divorce and her grandparents role as her role models -- (00:30) Biff Collie and Bryant talk about how Bryant had been born dead and had to be revived by her doctor -- (02:20) Bryant talks about how she was consistently sick as a child and her faith -- (03:38) Bryant talks about trying out for WKY Television and performing for the Gizmo Goodkin Talent Show -- (05:15) Bryant talks about being a regular on WKY until she got her own Anita Bryant Show -- (06:36) Bryant talks about her manager at WKY and how she learned her only singing lessons through him -- (07:27) Collie and Bryant discuss the country western music Bryant played in her youth and her variety in her shows -- (08:52) Bryant speaks on her ability to participate in shows, her nickname "Boats" as a reflection of her image, and her tom-boy status -- (10:14) Bryant reflects on her living with her grandparents and her grandpas conversion to Christianity -- (11:34) Bryant discusses her parents remerge and her discovery of faith -- (12:44) Bryant talks about living in Velma-Alma and her impact of her faith as a stabilizer of self-worth -- (14:20) Bryant talks about Christianity in schools and her desire for a reemergence of Christian foundations -- (15:26) Bryant tells of her struggles in mathematics and trying out for the Talent Scouts -- (16:30) Bryant talks about how she did not make the Ted Mack Show -- (16:58) Bryant and Collie discuss Patti Page and shying away from emulating anyone else -- (18:20) Bryant talks about the talent scouts who came to Oklahoma and moving to Tulsa causing her exposure through a production of South Pacific -- (21:18) Bryant tells a story of how she was dared by a professor to broaden her range and trying a new role in South Pacific -- (23:02) Bryant talks about Talent Scouts and being in the Miss America Pageant -- (24:48) Collie and Bryant talk about the Godfrey Show and Bryant's personal relationship with Arthur Godfrey among others through the show -- (25:45) Bryant reflects on traveling -- (26:05) Collie and Bryant discuss Bryant singing in Chicago's Blue Diamond Breakfast Club -- (27:03) Bryant talks about being in college and her lack of dating due to her career -- (27:57) Bryant talks about spouse Bob Green and her first million record sale -- (29:22) Bryant talks about working with Coco-Cola and working with various bottlers -- (30:42) Bryant discussed her preparation in theatre, producing Fantastics, and living in New York trying to make a name for herself on Broadway -- (32:26) Bryant reflects on the time consumption in theatre and her joining Florida Citrus -- (34:00) Collie and Bryant talk about her association to Florida Citrus and her desire to believe a product before being able to promote it -- (34:53) Bryant was called one of the most influential women in the world -- (35:10) Bryant says she was too busy, discusses where her income came from and her books -- (36:14) Collie and Bryant talk about Bryant's growing family and growing responsibility of success -- (38:01) Bryant talks about the payments received via shows and being self-sufficient -- (39:04) Bryant talks about people she meets on tour and refers to Lana Turner as a 'Little girl' she mothered -- (40:01) Bryant talks about Jack Jones and being in a helicopter with decoy helicopters that would be shot at -- (41:40) Bryant reflects on not being around her family and being with soldiers on Christmas -- (42:04) Collie and Bryant approach the subject of Bryant's sudden distance from popularity and her connection to faith -- (43:23) Bryant talks about her political connection and her feeling of being cornered before affecting private religious schools -- (45:01) Bryant talks about her accidental involvement in voicing her opinion about the sudden passing of a bill to make discrimination in housing illegal -- (46:20) Bryant talks about Save Our Children and joining local communities to vote down the bill HR-29 -- (48:58) Bryant talks about the media influence around her falling out with popular America -- (49:45) Bryant describes her time as painful, the Orange Juice Boycott, and the moral determination of public schooling -- (52:09) Collie and Bryant reflect on the media influence destroying an image aside from showing positivity -- (52:51) Collie and Bryant describe Bryant's self-desire to have the freedom of options for Bryant to choose who teaches their children -- (53:47) Bryant reasserts the humor of her personal attacks and Gods plan and her upcoming book 'Come Back' -- (54:54) Bryant talks about working in a ministry and how her agency backed out because of the pressures -- (56:13) Collie and Bryant reflect on orange juice's stance on Bryant after time and Bryant's low point -- (57:02) Bryant talks about coming back to Oklahoma and the eventual mental recovery -- (59:20) Bryant speaks about the rediscovery of faith and beginning the healing process -- (1:00:12) Bryant praises the restoration of relationships and tells the status of each of her children -- (1:01:32) Bryant talks about her upcoming projects and how she's partnering with Futuristic Enterprises -- (1:03:03) Collie and Bryant talk about the future video releases discussing Nasa projects -- (1:05:03) Bryant discusses the future of Futuristic Enterprises and Collie gives the information number while reflecting on the program -- (1:05:57) Bryant says she is bothered by the lack of values in programs on television and introducing children to the technological age -- (1:06:40) Collie welcomes Bryant back
